p.s: Worne has three major points in his speech.
Firstly he states the issue, secondly the general response and lastly his own opinion.
Each of them has its own way of getting presented.
The first point (ll. 1-11) is mostly letting the facts speak for themself with a formal and modest way of speaking.
The audience should not be distracted in getting the basic facts and data.
To keep himself credible enough the data he uses are mentioned as being report-resultsreport results like GCSE entry figures (l. 10).
Two major exceptions to the first point are both the introductionaryintroductary sentence and l. 5.
The former is using Can't, won't, don't as a way to sum up the national view towards learning languages in a silly and overcompressed way.
The compression keeps it relatively easy to swallow.
Because these words sound very similar and together make a very radical point it awakenesawakens the interest of the audience in both a humorous and serious way.
Us recommissioning our collective brains(l. 5) paraphrasing a simple sentence into overly formal language.
It parodies the perfect intellectuals that don't mind a lack of language learning overall, which is what his second part is about (ll. 12-15).
There he's trying to make fun of them by calling them perfect intellectuals(ll. 5) or squeezing in short ellipse like responses behind their points (ll. 13-14).
The audience therefore gets the impression that those selfproclaimedself-proclaimed intellectuals have actually very little understanding of the topic which shifts the credibility more towards Worne.
He makes use of this in the third part, his own opinion (ll. 16-35).
Here the content is underlined through certain striking words like vital , prosperity (l. 16), national security (l. 17), or break into(l. 21).
Words such as these paraphrase otherwise neutral content and add emotional connotations to crucial points since they tend to have a stronger impact on the audience.
vital makes something feel more important than simply saying important for instance.
Another cruicalcrucial stragedystrategy is him giving the audience as little room to dabatedebate him as possible.

Phrases like only(l. 24), There is no doubt (l. 30) or essential (l. 17) very much corner the listener into agreeing with him furthermore giving his point the impression of being undenieableundeniable.
At the end Worne approaches the audience personanalypersonally through inclusive language.
Not just via we(l. 33).
Phrases like parents of the UK(l. 32) (and I'm one)(l. 32) and we as parents(l. 33) support the two things.
They make to topic seem like a collective problem that affects everyone as well as giving a uniting factor.
A common problem is proven to be very strong at uniting different people.

This gets underlined through the children argument(l. 34) it synergizes very well with the previous inclusion of parents in that it creates a common problem and a common goal between Worne and the audience.

So over alloverall Worne first relies on pure facts and data, then shifts towards parodising the opposing party and ends with cornering the listener into agreeing with him both factually and personally.
